elements.clean_text: Fig. 1  Simplified schematic representation of the structure of a single crystal of 1. Color code: {V16O38(F)}4- clusters, medium grey; Ni atoms, black; N atoms, medium grey; C atoms, dark grey; O atoms, light grey. All H atoms are omitted for clarity.

elements.content:
<ce:figure id="fig2">
<ce:label>Fig. 2</ce:label>
<ce:caption>
<ce:simple-para view="all">(a) A space-filling view of the double-stranded left and right-handed helical chains along b exhibited by <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>. (b) The framework viewed along the [0<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>0<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>1] direction, showing two types of helical channels and achiral channels which are alternately arranged. All H atoms are omitted for clarity.</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:link locator="gr2"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
elements.clean_text: Fig. 2  (a) A space-filling view of the double-stranded left and right-handed helical chains along b exhibited by 1. (b) The framework viewed along the [001] direction, showing two types of helical channels and achiral channels which are alternately arranged. All H atoms are omitted for clarity.

<ce:section-title>Graphical abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para view="all">Unique organic–inorganic hybrid compounds have been separated under hydrothermal conditions, and are constructed of metal–organic complexes and cage-like vanadium clusters. They indicate novel structures and attractive magnetic properties. Furthermore, two new clusters [V<ce:inf loc="post">16</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">38</ce:inf>F]<ce:sup loc="post">4−</ce:sup> and [V<ce:inf loc="post">16</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">38</ce:inf>Br]<ce:sup loc="post">4−</ce:sup> are reported.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Graphical abstract

Unique organic-inorganic hybrid compounds have been separated under hydrothermal conditions, and are constructed of metal-organic complexes and cage-like vanadium clusters. They indicate novel structures and attractive magnetic properties. Furthermore, two new clusters [V16O38F]4- and [V16O38Br]4- are reported.

elements.clean_text:
Abstract

Under hydrothermal conditions, reactions of NaVO3, 4,4'-bipyridine and metal salts in the presence of Na2TeO3 and halide ions produce hybrid materials   [ M ( 4 ,   4   '   -bpy   )   2     ]   2   [   V   7   IV     V   9   V     O   38   X ] ⋅ ( 4 ,   4   '   -bpy   )   m   (   H   2   O   )   n     (bpy=bipyridine; M=Ni (1, 2), Co (3), Mn (4); X=F (1), Br (2), Cl (3, 4); m =1.5 (1, 2, 3), 1 (4); and n =3 for 1, 3.5 for 2, 2 for 3, 2.5 for 4). The variation of organic ligands can modify the inorganic oxide microstructure, just as the synthesis of   [ Ni ( 2 ,   2   '   -bpy   )   3     ]   3   [   V   8   IV     V   7   V     O   38   Cl ] ⋅ (   H   2   O   )   3    ( 5 )   by using 2,2'-bpy instead of 4,4'-bpy. Compounds 1-5 were characterized by elemental analyses, infrared spectroscopy, thermogravimetry, manganometric titration, temperature-dependent magnetic susceptibility measurement and single-crystal X-ray structure analysis. Compounds 1-4 are isostructural with cage-like [V16O38(X)]4- clusters incorporated into the 3D scaffolding afforded by [M(4,4'-bpy)2] n  subunits. There exist left and right-handed helical channels in the 3D cationic framework, filled with disordered 4,4'-bpy molecules. To the best of our knowledge, compounds 1 and 2 are the first examples of hybrid materials that contain V16 clusters with F- and Br- ions in the center, respectively. Compound 5 consists of [M(2,2'-bpy)3]2+,   [   V   8   IV     V   7   V     O   36   Cl   ]   6 -     cluster and H2O molecules. Magnetic studies prove that there exist ferrimagnetic interactions in 3 and 4.

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Introduction</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">The contemporary interest in the chemistry of polyoxometallates (POMs) stems from not only their potential applications in fields as diverse as catalysis, medicine, molecular magnetism and material science  but also their intriguing variety of architectures and topologies. The incorporation of metal–organic moieties into inorganic oxide clusters provides a powerful method for structural modification and synthesis of novel metallorganic–inorganic hybrid materials that combine different characteristics of the components to obtain unusual structures or properties. Oxovanadium compounds have provided a long-standing fascination for chemists due to their potential applications and their intriguing variety of topologies .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The contemporary interest in the chemistry of polyoxometallates (POMs) stems from not only their potential applications in fields as diverse as catalysis, medicine, molecular magnetism and material science  but also their intriguing variety of architectures and topologies. The incorporation of metal-organic moieties into inorganic oxide clusters provides a powerful method for structural modification and synthesis of novel metallorganic-inorganic hybrid materials that combine different characteristics of the components to obtain unusual structures or properties. Oxovanadium compounds have provided a long-standing fascination for chemists due to their potential applications and their intriguing variety of topologies .

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">In recent years, the significant interest in mixed-valence cage-like polyoxovanadate clusters  represents mainly the following aspects: (1) Cage-like polyoxovanadate clusters are very attractive in view of their diverse topologies. These clusters, containing mixed-valence vanadium centers, can act as host systems for a variety of neutral or anionic guest species, such as [V<ce:inf loc="post">14</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">36</ce:inf>X] (X<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Cl<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup>) , [V<ce:inf loc="post">15</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">36</ce:inf>X] (X<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Cl<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup>, Br<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> and CO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>) , [V<ce:inf loc="post">16</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">38</ce:inf>(X)] (X<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Cl<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup>, H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O) , [V<ce:inf loc="post">22</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">54</ce:inf>(X)] <mml:math altimg="si10.gif" overflow="scroll">

The central guest species in the shell exert templating effects on the electronic and framework structures of the host metal-oxide shells . (2) The important family of magnetic polyoxometallates involves the mixed valence V<ce:sup loc="post">IV/V</ce:sup> oxometallates . Magnetic studies performed on the mixed valence vanadium (IV/V) clusters arising from the full or partial deloclization of single 3d electrons of the V<ce:sup loc="post">IV</ce:sup> ions over both V<ce:sup loc="post">IV</ce:sup> and V<ce:sup loc="post">V</ce:sup> have shown antiferromagnetic coupling and a few ferromagnetic coupling . (3) The mixed-valence vanadium oxide clusters have luminescence properties. This class of compounds could be active in photo-oxidation reactions and a potential photocatalyst, which is worth further investigating .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In recent years, the significant interest in mixed-valence cage-like polyoxovanadate clusters  represents mainly the following aspects: (1) Cage-like polyoxovanadate clusters are very attractive in view of their diverse topologies. These clusters, containing mixed-valence vanadium centers, can act as host systems for a variety of neutral or anionic guest species, such as [V14O36X] (X=Cl-) , [V15O36X] (X=Cl-, Br- and CO3) , [V16O38(X)] (X=Cl-, H2O) , [V22O54(X)]   X = (   ClO   4     -   ,    SCN   -    and    CH   3     COO   -   )    and [V18O42(X)] (X=H2O, Cl-, Br-, I-, SO4 and VO4)  clusters. The central guest species in the shell exert templating effects on the electronic and framework structures of the host metal-oxide shells . (2) The important family of magnetic polyoxometallates involves the mixed valence VIV/V oxometallates . Magnetic studies performed on the mixed valence vanadium (IV/V) clusters arising from the full or partial deloclization of single 3d electrons of the VIV ions over both VIV and VV have shown antiferromagnetic coupling and a few ferromagnetic coupling . (3) The mixed-valence vanadium oxide clusters have luminescence properties. This class of compounds could be active in photo-oxidation reactions and a potential photocatalyst, which is worth further investigating .

We are currently exploring to design and develop organic–inorganic hybrid materials by the amalgamation of cage-like mixed-valence vanadium clusters with metal–organic complexes. The mixed-valence vanadium clusters that fuse paramagnetic transition metal complexes might be of interest in molecular magnetism . During this ongoing effort, different paramagnetic metal ions have been introduced into the reaction system, such as manganese (II), cobalt (II) and nickel (II). elements.clean_text: Owing to the synergistic interaction between the metal-organic and inorganic components, this class of compounds reveals some remarkable properties. We are currently exploring to design and develop organic-inorganic hybrid materials by the amalgamation of cage-like mixed-valence vanadium clusters with metal-organic complexes. The mixed-valence vanadium clusters that fuse paramagnetic transition metal complexes might be of interest in molecular magnetism . During this ongoing effort, different paramagnetic metal ions have been introduced into the reaction system, such as manganese (II), cobalt (II) and nickel (II). As a result, magnetic materials are obtained through combining paramagnetic metal ions and   [   V   7   IV     V   9   V     O   38   X   ]   4 -     clusters. In addition, the significant role of organic components in controlling the inorganic oxide microstructure was investigated by using different organic ligands. In this paper, we describe the synthesis and characterization of hybrid materials 1-5. The magnetic properties of compounds 3, 4 and 5 are reported as well.

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Experimental</ce:section-title><ce:section-title>General remarks</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">All reagents were readily available from commercial sources and were used as received without further purification. The IR spectra in KBr pellets were recorded in the range 400–4000<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> with an Alpha Centaurt FT/IR Spectrophotometer. Elemental Analyses (C, H and N) were performed with a Perkin–Elmer 2400 CHN Elemental Analyzer. M and V were determined with a PLASMASPEC (I) ICP atomic emission spectrometer. X-ray photoelectron spectrometry (XPS) spectra were measured on an ESCALAB spectrometer. Thermogravimetric analyses were carried out using a Pyris Diamond TG/DTA instrument, with a heating rate of 10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C/min, under a nitrogen atmosphere. Magnetic susceptibility and magnetization data were collected over the temperature range 1.8–300<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K in an applied field up to 50<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>kOe on a Quantum Design MPMS-5 SQUID magnetometer.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Experimental

General remarks

All reagents were readily available from commercial sources and were used as received without further purification. The IR spectra in KBr pellets were recorded in the range 400-4000cm-1 with an Alpha Centaurt FT/IR Spectrophotometer. Elemental Analyses (C, H and N) were performed with a Perkin-Elmer 2400 CHN Elemental Analyzer. M and V were determined with a PLASMASPEC (I) ICP atomic emission spectrometer. X-ray photoelectron spectrometry (XPS) spectra were measured on an ESCALAB spectrometer. Thermogravimetric analyses were carried out using a Pyris Diamond TG/DTA instrument, with a heating rate of 10°C/min, under a nitrogen atmosphere. Magnetic susceptibility and magnetization data were collected over the temperature range 1.8-300K in an applied field up to 50kOe on a Quantum Design MPMS-5 SQUID magnetometer.

Preparation

Synthesis of   [ Ni ( 4 ,   4   '   - bpy   )   2     ]   2   [   V   7   IV     V   9   V     O   38   F ] ⋅ ( 4 ,   4   '   - bpy   )   1.5   (   H   2   O   )   3    ( 1 )   

A mixture of NaVO3 (122mg, 1mmol), Na2TeO3 (222mg, 1mmol), Ni(CH3COO)2 (177mg, 1mmol), 4,4'-bipyridine (50mg, 0.38mmol), HF (40%, 0.2mL), CH3CH2OH (2mL) and H2O (5mL) was stirred for ca. 1h in air until it was homogeneous, and adjusted by CH3COOH to pH 4.6, and then transferred and sealed in a 16mL Teflon-lined stainless steel container. After heated to 170°C under autogenously pressure for 4d, the bomb was cooled down to room temperature. Black octahedron block crystals of 1 along with an amorphous grey impurity were filtered from the colorless mother liquor, washed by distilled water and air-dried at room temperature. The crystals were mechanically separated from the powdery grey impurity to give a yield of 61% (based on V), and were stable in air and insoluble in water and common organic solvents. IR (KBr, cm-1):     ν   ˜   = 3446   (m), 1601 (m), 1559 (m), 1530 (m), 1487 (m), 1408 (m), 1066 (m), 983 (m), 813 (m), 733 (m), 670 (m), 657 (m), 631 (m), 507 (m), 459 (m), 418 (m), 403 (m). Elemental Anal. Calc. for Ni2C55H50N11O41V16F: C, 26.72; H, 2.04; N, 6.23; Ni, 4.75; V, 32.97. Found: C, 27.01; H, 2.27; N, 6.54; Ni, 4.27; V, 32.79%.

A mixture of NaVO3 (183mg, 1.5mmol), Na2TeO3 (220mg, 1mmol), Ni(CH3COO)2 (177mg, 1mmol), 2,2'-bipyridine (50mg, 0.38mmol), HCl (0.1mL), CH3CH2OH (2mL) and H2O (5mL) was stirred for ca. 45min in air until it was homogeneous, and adjusted by CH3COOH to pH 5.5, and then transferred and sealed in a 16mL Teflon-lined stainless steel container. The crystals were mechanically separated from the grey impurity to give a yield of 51% (based on V), and were stable in air and insoluble in water and common organic solvents. <ce:section-title>Crystal structure determination</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">Black crystals of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>5</ce:bold> were glued on to glass fibers. Data were collected at 298(2)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K on a Rigaku R-AXIS RAPID IP diffractometer with Mo K<ce:italic>α</ce:italic> monochromated radiation (<ce:italic>λ</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.71073<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å). The structures were solved by direct methods and refined by full-matrix least-squares methods on <ce:italic>F</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup> with the <ce:small-caps>shelxtl</ce:small-caps> software package. An empirical absorption correction was applied. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically and hydrogen atoms were included at idealized positions and refined by use of the riding model. A summary of the crystallographic data of complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>5</ce:bold> is presented in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="tbl1"></ce:float-anchor>.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Crystal structure determination

Black crystals of 1-5 were glued on to glass fibers. Data were collected at 298(2)K on a Rigaku R-AXIS RAPID IP diffractometer with Mo Kα monochromated radiation (λ =0.71073Å). The structures were solved by direct methods and refined by full-matrix least-squares methods on F 2 with the shelxtl software package. An empirical absorption correction was applied. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically and hydrogen atoms were included at idealized positions and refined by use of the riding model. A summary of the crystallographic data of complexes 1-5 is presented in  .

elements.content:
<ce:section-title>Results and discussion</ce:section-title><ce:section-title>Synthesis</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">The syntheses of the compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>′ , <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> and the spherical mixed-valence host–guest V15 cluster <ce:bold>5</ce:bold> are summarized in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig9"></ce:float-anchor>. The {V<ce:inf loc="post">16</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">38</ce:inf>} core has been observed in some well characterized compounds containing the same numbers of reduced vanadium (IV) sites . The basic {V<ce:inf loc="post">16</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">38</ce:inf>} shell in all these compounds is built up from 16 VO<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf> distorted square pyramids that share edges and corners through two μ<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>- and 20 μ<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-oxygen atoms, respectively. The shell could encapsulate Cl<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> ions and H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O molecules that exert templating effects on the electronic and framework structures of the host metal-oxide shells. However, we have successfully obtained <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> with a suitable fluoride and bromide ion source (HF and HBr) in the reaction. Compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is the first example of hybrid materials that contain a [V<ce:inf loc="post">16</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">38</ce:inf>F]<ce:sup loc="post">4−</ce:sup> cluster and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> is the first example of hybrid materials that contain a [V<ce:inf loc="post">16</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">38</ce:inf>Br]<ce:sup loc="post">4−</ce:sup> cluster. Furthermore, the [V<ce:inf loc="post">16</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">38</ce:inf>F]<ce:sup loc="post">4−</ce:sup> and [V<ce:inf loc="post">16</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">38</ce:inf>Br]<ce:sup loc="post">4−</ce:sup> clusters present different numbers of reduced vanadium (IV) sites compared to the reported {V<ce:inf loc="post">16</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">38</ce:inf>} core.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Results and discussion

Synthesis

The syntheses of the compounds 1, 1' , 2, 3, 4 and the spherical mixed-valence host-guest V15 cluster 5 are summarized in  . The {V16O38} core has been observed in some well characterized compounds containing the same numbers of reduced vanadium (IV) sites . The basic {V16O38} shell in all these compounds is built up from 16 VO5 distorted square pyramids that share edges and corners through two μ2- and 20 μ3-oxygen atoms, respectively. The shell could encapsulate Cl- ions and H2O molecules that exert templating effects on the electronic and framework structures of the host metal-oxide shells. However, we have successfully obtained 1 and 2 with a suitable fluoride and bromide ion source (HF and HBr) in the reaction. Compound 1 is the first example of hybrid materials that contain a [V16O38F]4- cluster and 2 is the first example of hybrid materials that contain a [V16O38Br]4- cluster. Furthermore, the [V16O38F]4- and [V16O38Br]4- clusters present different numbers of reduced vanadium (IV) sites compared to the reported {V16O38} core.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">Thinking about the comparability of the first-row transition metals, different paramagnetic metal ions Co(II), Ni(II) and Mn(II) were introduced into the reaction system. Compounds <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> were prepared under similar conditions. In order to study the effect of the organic ligands on the inorganic oxide microstructure, we intended to replace 4,4′-bpy with other organic ligands containing nitrogen (i.e., 2,2′-bpy and en). Based on this thought, compound <ce:bold>5</ce:bold> was obtained by reaction of 2,2′-bpy with NaVO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>, Na<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>TeO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> and HCl in acidic aqueous solution (pH 5.5). Though ethanol is not necessary for the formation of compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>5</ce:bold>, a large number of parallel experiments indicate that the presence of a small quantity of ethanol could improve the yield and purity of these compounds.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Thinking about the comparability of the first-row transition metals, different paramagnetic metal ions Co(II), Ni(II) and Mn(II) were introduced into the reaction system. Compounds 3 and 4 were prepared under similar conditions. In order to study the effect of the organic ligands on the inorganic oxide microstructure, we intended to replace 4,4'-bpy with other organic ligands containing nitrogen (i.e., 2,2'-bpy and en). Based on this thought, compound 5 was obtained by reaction of 2,2'-bpy with NaVO3, Na2TeO3 and HCl in acidic aqueous solution (pH 5.5). Though ethanol is not necessary for the formation of compounds 1-5, a large number of parallel experiments indicate that the presence of a small quantity of ethanol could improve the yield and purity of these compounds.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">Significantly, the presence of Na<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>TeO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> is necessary for the formation of compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>5</ce:bold>. When the reactions were performed in the absence of Na<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>TeO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>, nothing could be obtained except for some yellow precipitation, likely corresponding to complexes of V<ce:sup loc="post">V</ce:sup>. Consequently, it appears that Na<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>TeO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> exerts the role of reducer for V<ce:sup loc="post">V</ce:sup>. Taking into account the characteristic comparability of identical group elements, we replaced Na<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>TeO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> with an equal amount of Na<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>SO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> or Na<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>SeO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> in the reaction system. When Na<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>SO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> was used, compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>5</ce:bold> cannot be obtained. However, compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>5</ce:bold> could be obtained when Na<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>SeO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> was used instead of Na<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>TeO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>, but at a cost of the yield and crystal quality of these compounds. It can be concluded that the reductive ability of Na<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>TeO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> and Na<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>SeO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> are comparative and both are weaker than that of Na<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>SO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>, which indicates that weak reducer is propitious to the formation of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>5</ce:bold>. During our experiments, we also found that <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>5</ce:bold> cannot be obtained when some other common reducers such as oxalic acid, ethylenediamine and hydrazinium sulfate were used instead of Na<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>TeO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Significantly, the presence of Na2TeO3 is necessary for the formation of compounds 1-5. When the reactions were performed in the absence of Na2TeO3, nothing could be obtained except for some yellow precipitation, likely corresponding to complexes of VV. Consequently, it appears that Na2TeO3 exerts the role of reducer for VV. Taking into account the characteristic comparability of identical group elements, we replaced Na2TeO3 with an equal amount of Na2SO3 or Na2SeO3 in the reaction system. When Na2SO3 was used, compounds 1-5 cannot be obtained. However, compounds 1-5 could be obtained when Na2SeO3 was used instead of Na2TeO3, but at a cost of the yield and crystal quality of these compounds. It can be concluded that the reductive ability of Na2TeO3 and Na2SeO3 are comparative and both are weaker than that of Na2SO3, which indicates that weak reducer is propitious to the formation of 1-5. During our experiments, we also found that 1-5 cannot be obtained when some other common reducers such as oxalic acid, ethylenediamine and hydrazinium sulfate were used instead of Na2TeO3.

elements.clean_text:
Description of the crystal structure

Single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that compounds 1-4 are isomorphous. They have similar molecular formulas and crystal structures, hence only the structure of 1 will be discussed in detail. The crystal structure of 1 can be described as a three-dimensional framework constructed from helical metal-organic coordination polymers [{Nibpy}2+] n  cations, [V16O38(F)]4- cluster anions, guest 4,4'-bpy and water molecules ( ). The [V16O38F]4- cluster, with S4 symmetry, is composed of a {V16O38} shell with an encapsulated F- ion in the center. The 16 V atoms are arranged at the surface of the shell with radius of 3.57±0.21Å from the central haloid ion. The host {V16O38} shell consists of 16 VO5 square pyramids by sharing edges and corners with 20 μ3-O atoms and 2 μ2-O atoms. The other 16 oxygen atoms are terminal in the polar positions of the 16 VO5 square pyramids. The geometry around vanadium (V1) in the 4 VO5 units is defined by four basal μ3-O groups and an apical μ-oxygen which in turn is linearly bonded to the Ni(II) center and then {V1-O-Ni-O-V1} bonds, which link [V16O38F]4- clusters, are formed. The square pyramidal geometry around vanadium (V2 and V3) in eight of the 16 VO5 groups is defined by a terminal oxo group and four μ3-O atoms of the shell. The geometry around vanadium (V4) in the remaining 4 VO5 units is defined by three μ3-O groups, one μ2-O group and one terminal oxygen atom.

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">In the metal–organic coordination polymers, each Ni atom is 6-coordinate and shows a “4+2” distorted octahedron geometry. The equatorial plane is defined by four nitrogen donors of four 4,4′-bpy ligands (Ni–N: 2.141–2.144<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å). The axial positions are occupied by two bridging oxygen atoms coming from two different [V<ce:inf loc="post">16</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">38</ce:inf>(F)]<ce:sup loc="post">4−</ce:sup> clusters (Ni–O: 2.034<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å). An unusual feature of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is that the transition-metal Ni<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> and organic 4,4′-bpy are joined by N atoms to generate rectangular left and right-handed helical channels alternately, with N–Ni–N bond angles ranging from 89.38° to 91.2°, and these channels can be seen in a view along the [0<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>0<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>1] direction (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig2"></ce:float-anchor>b). Furthermore, large chiral channels that are suitable for incorporating organic guest molecules exist between the helices, in which disordered 4,4′-bpy as guest molecules reside. Interestingly, each chiral channel is formed by a double-stranded helical chain intertwined by homochiral polymeric chains (a).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In the metal-organic coordination polymers, each Ni atom is 6-coordinate and shows a "4+2" distorted octahedron geometry. The equatorial plane is defined by four nitrogen donors of four 4,4'-bpy ligands (Ni-N: 2.141-2.144Å). The axial positions are occupied by two bridging oxygen atoms coming from two different [V16O38(F)]4- clusters (Ni-O: 2.034Å). An unusual feature of 1 is that the transition-metal Ni2+ and organic 4,4'-bpy are joined by N atoms to generate rectangular left and right-handed helical channels alternately, with N-Ni-N bond angles ranging from 89.38° to 91.2°, and these channels can be seen in a view along the [001] direction ( b). Furthermore, large chiral channels that are suitable for incorporating organic guest molecules exist between the helices, in which disordered 4,4'-bpy as guest molecules reside. Interestingly, each chiral channel is formed by a double-stranded helical chain intertwined by homochiral polymeric chains (a).

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">In the structure of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, the [V<ce:inf loc="post">16</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">38</ce:inf>(F)]<ce:sup loc="post">4−</ce:sup> cluster acts as a tetradentate ligand coordinating to four Ni<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> ions through the terminal oxo groups of vanadium sites with Ni–O distances ranging from 2.034 to 2.132<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å. The linkage of Ni atoms and [V<ce:inf loc="post">16</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">38</ce:inf>(F)]<ce:sup loc="post">4−</ce:sup> clusters form a diamond framework by replacing each C in diamond with a [V<ce:inf loc="post">16</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">38</ce:inf>(F)]<ce:sup loc="post">4−</ce:sup> cluster and each C–C with a Ni(II) center (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig3"></ce:float-anchor>). This connectivity behavior may enhance the stability of the framework of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>. Additionally, the metal–organic coordination polymer cations [{Nibpy}<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup>]<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>
</ce:inf> connect with [V<ce:inf loc="post">16</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">38</ce:inf>(F)]<ce:sup loc="post">4−</ce:sup> clusters to form a twofold interpenetrating three-dimensional structure through the terminal oxo groups of vanadium sites (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig4"></ce:float-anchor>). Unlike many other solids with interpenetrating networks, the extent of interpenetration in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> does not fill all the available voids but leaves a significant portion in the form of rectangular extended channels that are occupied by disordered 4,4′-bpy molecules. To the best of our knowledge, the occurrence of this interpenetrating net, composed of large polyoxoanion clusters and a metal–organic coordination polymer, is unprecedented. It shows that the incorporation of large polyoxoanion clusters could provide efficient cation–anion packing to prevent interpenetration of the cationic polymers.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In the structure of 1, the [V16O38(F)]4- cluster acts as a tetradentate ligand coordinating to four Ni2+ ions through the terminal oxo groups of vanadium sites with Ni-O distances ranging from 2.034 to 2.132Å. The linkage of Ni atoms and [V16O38(F)]4- clusters form a diamond framework by replacing each C in diamond with a [V16O38(F)]4- cluster and each C-C with a Ni(II) center ( ). This connectivity behavior may enhance the stability of the framework of 1. Additionally, the metal-organic coordination polymer cations [{Nibpy}2+] n  connect with [V16O38(F)]4- clusters to form a twofold interpenetrating three-dimensional structure through the terminal oxo groups of vanadium sites ( ). Unlike many other solids with interpenetrating networks, the extent of interpenetration in 1 does not fill all the available voids but leaves a significant portion in the form of rectangular extended channels that are occupied by disordered 4,4'-bpy molecules. To the best of our knowledge, the occurrence of this interpenetrating net, composed of large polyoxoanion clusters and a metal-organic coordination polymer, is unprecedented. It shows that the incorporation of large polyoxoanion clusters could provide efficient cation-anion packing to prevent interpenetration of the cationic polymers.

elements.clean_text: The structure of the [V16O38Br]4- cluster in compound 2 is similar to the [V16O38F]4- cluster, but the bond lengths and bond angles are different, see . In the case of compounds 1, 2 and 3, the polyoxovanadate clusters are composed of a [V16O38] shell with an encapsulated F-, Br- or Cl- ion in the center, respectively. This is confirmed by XPS measurements in the F1s, Br3d and Cl2p energy region, respectively. The XPS spectra of compounds 1, 2 and 3 show peaks at 684eV, 70eV and 198eV, respectively, attributable to F-, Br- and Cl- (). The host shells are formed by using the template function of the anionic guest and are dependent on its shape and size. The van der Waals radii of the guests must of course be smaller than those of the cavities . The nearest distance from the center of the [V16O38F]4-, [V16O38Br]4- and [V16O38Cl]4- clusters to the O atoms of the periphery is 3.318Å, 3.358Å and 3.341Å, and to the 16 V atoms at the surface of the shell is 3.396Å, 3.397Å and 3.390Å, respectively. It is possible that the V16 cluster encapsulates negatively charged halide ions with significant different radii (F- =1.33Å, Br- =1.96Å, Cl- =1.81Å and O2- =1.32Å). When HCl was replaced with HI, however, the expected product was not obtained. Because the effective ionic radius of the I- ion (2.20Å) is larger, the I- ion cannot be encapsulated by the shell of [V16O38]. Also, we have tried to replace halide ions with     SO   4     2 -   ,    CO   3     2 -   ,    NO   3     -    and    ClO   4     -     in order to study the templating effects of the central ions, but failed. It is due to that the assembly of the host cage is probably determined by the shape and symmetry of the small guest molecule. Additionally the host cage tends to adapt not only to the shape of the guest system, but also to its molecular electrostatic potentials distribution . So in compounds 1, 2 and 3, global halide ions with high symmetry and suited shape, size and molecular electrostatic potential distributions are propitious to form the {V16O38} shell.

elements.clean_text: When 2,2'-bpy was used instead of 4,4'-bpy, compound 5 was obtained. Compound 5 is constructed from [V15O36Cl]6- anions and [Ni(2,2'-bpy)3]2+ cations via electrostatic and aryl-aryl interactions (). Each C atom of three 2,2'-bpy coordinating to the Ni(3) atom is disordered over two positions, and the best refinement has been obtained with occupancy factors of about 0.5 and 0.5 (). The spherical cluster [V15O36Cl]6- formally contains 15 V centers arranged on the surface of a sphere at a distance of 3.42±0.11Å from the center of the cluster in which the Cl- resides ( ). For5, bond valence sums calculations reveal that the [V15O36Cl] clusters have six negative charges. The average value calculated for the oxidation state of V is 4.423, very close to the value of 4.467 for     V   8   IV     V   7   V    . This conclusion and the result of the manganometric titration of VIV sites correspond to the stated formulation of 5.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">If 4,4′-bpy was substituted by en, compound [Ni(en)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>][V<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">14</ce:inf>] was synthesized in our reaction system. The mixed-valence vanadium oxide [V<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">14</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> layers contain infinite zigzag chains composed of edge-sharing VO<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf> square pyramids. Adjacent chains are connected through corner-shared VO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> tetrahedra to form a layer structure. Compound [Ni(en)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>][V<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">14</ce:inf>] has been synthesized in our reaction system, though it can be obtained under other conditions . Several different polyoxovanadate clusters, such as [V<ce:inf loc="post">16</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">38</ce:inf>X]<ce:sup loc="post">4−</ce:sup>, [V<ce:inf loc="post">15</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">36</ce:inf>Cl]<ce:sup loc="post">6−</ce:sup> and [V<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">14</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup>, have been obtained by using organic ligands with different functionalities, which indicate that the organic components could modify the inorganic oxide microstructure. So under similar conditions, hybrid materials containing different polyoxometallate clusters are prepared by selecting different organic ligands.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: If 4,4'-bpy was substituted by en, compound [Ni(en)2][V6O14] was synthesized in our reaction system. The mixed-valence vanadium oxide [V6O14]2- layers contain infinite zigzag chains composed of edge-sharing VO5 square pyramids. Adjacent chains are connected through corner-shared VO4 tetrahedra to form a layer structure. Compound [Ni(en)2][V6O14] has been synthesized in our reaction system, though it can be obtained under other conditions . Several different polyoxovanadate clusters, such as [V16O38X]4-, [V15O36Cl]6- and [V6O14]2-, have been obtained by using organic ligands with different functionalities, which indicate that the organic components could modify the inorganic oxide microstructure. So under similar conditions, hybrid materials containing different polyoxometallate clusters are prepared by selecting different organic ligands.

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Thermogravimetric analysis</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">Thermogravimetric analysis of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>4</ce:bold> reveals a continuous weight loss (36.7% for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, 35.5% for <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, 36.1% for <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> and 35.8% for <ce:bold>4</ce:bold>) until 429<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, 421<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, 431<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C and 428<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, respectively, corresponding to the removal of water molecules, the guest 4,4′-bpy molecule and four coordinated 4,4′-bpy molecules (calc.36.1% for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, 36.2% for <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, 36.9% for <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> and 36.3% for <ce:bold>4</ce:bold>). In compound <ce:bold>5</ce:bold>, the TG curve shows four weight loss steps, which suggests a multiple-stage decomposition process. Heating from about 25 to 130<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C leads to the loss (weight loss of ca. 2.03%) of three crystal H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O molecules per formula unit (calc. 1.79%). The next three weight loss steps (45.23%), occurring between 180 and 596<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, correspond to the loss of three 2,2′-bpy molecules per formula unit (calc. 46.68%).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Thermogravimetric analysis

Thermogravimetric analysis of 1-4 reveals a continuous weight loss (36.7% for 1, 35.5% for 2, 36.1% for 3 and 35.8% for 4) until 429°C, 421°C, 431°C and 428°C, respectively, corresponding to the removal of water molecules, the guest 4,4'-bpy molecule and four coordinated 4,4'-bpy molecules (calc.36.1% for 1, 36.2% for 2, 36.9% for 3 and 36.3% for 4). In compound 5, the TG curve shows four weight loss steps, which suggests a multiple-stage decomposition process. Heating from about 25 to 130°C leads to the loss (weight loss of ca. 2.03%) of three crystal H2O molecules per formula unit (calc. 1.79%). The next three weight loss steps (45.23%), occurring between 180 and 596°C, correspond to the loss of three 2,2'-bpy molecules per formula unit (calc. 46.68%).

elements.clean_text:
Magnetic properties of compounds 3, 4 and 5 

The variable-temperature magnetic susceptibilities of 1', 3 and 4 were measured between 2 and 300K at 10000Oe. The magnetic data of compound 1' is included for comparison. The thermal variations of χ m T and 1/χ m are displayed in   (where χ m is the measured magnetic susceptibility). In the case of compounds 1', 3 and 4, the χ m T products at 300K are 3.02emuKmol-1 (4.92 μ B), 6.47emuKmol-1 (7.19 μ B) and 8.82emuKmol-1 (8.40 μ B), respectively. The χ m T values of 1' and 4 are smaller than the expected values for two uncorrelated M2+ (Ni2+: S =1, Mn2+: S =5/2) and seven V4+ (S =1/2) centers per formula unit (χ m T (1')=4.63emuKmol-1, 6.08 μ B; χ m T (4)=11.38emuKmol-1, 9.54 μ B), but the χ m T value of 3(two uncoupled S =3/2 for Co2+, seven uncoupled S =1 for V4+) is higher than the expected value (χ m T (3)=6.38emuKmol-1, 7.14 μ B). The products χ m T increase on cooling to a maximum 5.93emuKmol-1 at 8K for 1', 9.00emuKmol-1 at 50K for 3 and 12.70emuKmol-1 at 48K for 4, which indicates the presence of ferrimagnetic exchange coupling. Subsequently, the curves drop abruptly below 8K, 50K and 48K for 1', 3 and 4, respectively, which may be caused by the zero-field splitting contributions, intercluster magnetic interactions or saturation effects are likely to influence the data in this temperature range. The measured data of 1', 3 and 4 were fitted by using the Curie-Weiss equation χ m = C m/(T - θ) at T >150K, where C m is the Curie constant and θ is the Weiss constant, with C m =2.39emuKmol-1 and θ =65.85K for 1', C m =5.32emuKmol-1 and θ =55.91K for 3 and C m =7.16emuKmol-1 and θ =60.22K for 4.

elements.clean_text: The variable-temperature magnetic susceptibility of 5 was also measured between 2 and 300K at 10000Oe. χ m T versus T shows a value of 6.68emuKmol-1 (7.31 μ B) at 300K, higher than the expected total value (6.00emuKmol-1, 6.93 μ B) of eight uncoupled S =1/2 spins of V4+ atoms and three uncoupled S =1 spins of Ni2+ atoms (). The χ m T values remain almost constant from 300K to 18K, and then decrease on further cooling, reaching a value of 3.74emuKmol-1 at 2K, which indicates paramagnetic properties in compound 5. The fit for the curve of the 1/χ m versus T plot of 5 to the Curie-Weiss law gives a good result in the temperature range 2-300K with C m =6.66emuKmol-1 and θ =0.20K (see   ).

elements.content:
<ce:section-title>Conclusion</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">In summary, the combination of cage-like polyoxovanadate clusters with metal–organic complexes provides a series of hybrid materials <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>5</ce:bold> with different structures and physical properties. Compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>4</ce:bold> have 3D coordination complex [{Mbpy}<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup>]<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>
</ce:inf> cationic scaffoldings that incorporate vanadium oxide clusters into their void spaces. The successful preparation of compound <ce:bold>5</ce:bold> and [Ni(en)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>][V<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">14</ce:inf>] indicates that organic ligands can dramatically influence the inorganic oxide microstructure. The effects of different reaction factors were discussed in the paper, such as the source of the transition metal salts, organic ligands and central templates, which provide an optional method to design and synthesize novel hybrid materials. Furthermore, the magnetic properties of compounds <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> could make them excellent candidates for potential applications in magnetic materials.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In summary, the combination of cage-like polyoxovanadate clusters with metal-organic complexes provides a series of hybrid materials 1-5 with different structures and physical properties. Compounds 1-4 have 3D coordination complex [{Mbpy}2+] n  cationic scaffoldings that incorporate vanadium oxide clusters into their void spaces. The successful preparation of compound 5 and [Ni(en)2][V6O14] indicates that organic ligands can dramatically influence the inorganic oxide microstructure. The effects of different reaction factors were discussed in the paper, such as the source of the transition metal salts, organic ligands and central templates, which provide an optional method to design and synthesize novel hybrid materials. Furthermore, the magnetic properties of compounds 3 and 4 could make them excellent candidates for potential applications in magnetic materials.

Supplementary data associated with this article can be found, in the online version, at doi:10.1016/j.poly.2006.11.050.

</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">A mixture of NaVO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> (122<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg, 1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol), Na<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>TeO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> (222<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg, 1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol), Ni(CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>COO)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> (177<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg, 1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol), 4,4′-bipyridine (50<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg, 0.38<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol), HF (40%, 0.2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL), CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>OH (2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL) and H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL) was stirred for ca. 1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h in air until it was homogeneous, and adjusted by CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>COOH to pH 4.6, and then transferred and sealed in a 16<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL Teflon-lined stainless steel container. After heated to 170<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C under autogenously pressure for 4d, the bomb was cooled down to room temperature. Black octahedron block crystals of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> along with an amorphous grey impurity were filtered from the colorless mother liquor, washed by distilled water and air-dried at room temperature. The crystals were mechanically separated from the powdery grey impurity to give a yield of 61% (based on V), and were stable in air and insoluble in water and common organic solvents. Preparation

Synthesis of   [ Ni ( 4 ,   4   '   - bpy   )   2     ]   2   [   V   7   IV     V   9   V     O   38   F ] ⋅ ( 4 ,   4   '   - bpy   )   1.5   (   H   2   O   )   3    ( 1 )   

A mixture of NaVO3 (122mg, 1mmol), Na2TeO3 (222mg, 1mmol), Ni(CH3COO)2 (177mg, 1mmol), 4,4'-bipyridine (50mg, 0.38mmol), HF (40%, 0.2mL), CH3CH2OH (2mL) and H2O (5mL) was stirred for ca. 1h in air until it was homogeneous, and adjusted by CH3COOH to pH 4.6, and then transferred and sealed in a 16mL Teflon-lined stainless steel container. After heated to 170°C under autogenously pressure for 4d, the bomb was cooled down to room temperature. Black octahedron block crystals of 1 along with an amorphous grey impurity were filtered from the colorless mother liquor, washed by distilled water and air-dried at room temperature. The crystals were mechanically separated from the powdery grey impurity to give a yield of 61% (based on V), and were stable in air and insoluble in water and common organic solvents. IR (KBr, cm-1):     ν   ˜   = 3446   (m), 1601 (m), 1559 (m), 1530 (m), 1487 (m), 1408 (m), 1066 (m), 983 (m), 813 (m), 733 (m), 670 (m), 657 (m), 631 (m), 507 (m), 459 (m), 418 (m), 403 (m). Elemental Anal. Calc. for Ni2C55H50N11O41V16F: C, 26.72; H, 2.04; N, 6.23; Ni, 4.75; V, 32.97. Found: C, 27.01; H, 2.27; N, 6.54; Ni, 4.27; V, 32.79%.

The reaction was carried out in the same way as for 1 except that HBr (0.25mL) was used instead of HCl. Yield: 62% based on V. IR (KBr, cm-1):     ν   ˜   = 3442   (m), 1600 (m), 1548 (m), 1516 (m), 1479 (m), 1412 (m), 990 (m), 946 (m), 731 (m), 669 (m), 656 (m), 631 (m), 472 (w), 417 (m). Elemental Anal. Calc. for Ni2C55H51N11O41.5V16Br: C, 25.98; H, 2.02; N, 6.06; Ni, 4.62; V, 32.06. Found: C, 26.21; H, 2.19; N, 6.35; Ni, 4.34; V, 29.87%.

Synthesis of   [ Co ( 4 ,   4   '   - bpy   )   2     ]   2   [   V   7   IV     V   9   V     O   38   Cl ] ⋅ ( 4 ,   4   '   - bpy   )   1.5   (   H   2   O   )   2    ( 3 )   

The preparation of 3 was similar to that of 1 except that Co(CH3COO)2 (177mg, 1mmol) was used in place of Ni(CH3COO)2. Yield: 59% based on V; IR (KBr, cm-1):     ν   ˜   = 3680   (w), 3446 (w), 2360 (m), 1743 (m), 1692 (m), 1646 (m), 1546 m, 1531 (m), 1515 (m), 1482 (m), 1411 (m), 985 (m), 816 (w), 677 (m), 575 (w), 455 (w). The reaction was carried out in the same way as for 1 except that MnSO4 (151mg, 1mmol) was used instead of Ni(CH3COO)2. <ce:section-title>Description of the crystal structure</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">Single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>4</ce:bold> are isomorphous. They have similar molecular formulas and crystal structures, hence only the structure of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> will be discussed in detail. The crystal structure of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> can be described as a three-dimensional framework constructed from helical metal–organic coordination polymers [{Nibpy}<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup>]<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>
</ce:inf> cations, [V<ce:inf loc="post">16</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">38</ce:inf>(F)]<ce:sup loc="post">4−</ce:sup> cluster anions, guest 4,4′-bpy and water molecules (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig1"></ce:float-anchor>). The [V<ce:inf loc="post">16</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">38</ce:inf>F]<ce:sup loc="post">4−</ce:sup> cluster, with S<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> symmetry, is composed of a {V<ce:inf loc="post">16</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">38</ce:inf>} shell with an encapsulated F<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> ion in the center. The 16 V atoms are arranged at the surface of the shell with radius of 3.57<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>±<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.21<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å from the central haloid ion. The host {V<ce:inf loc="post">16</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">38</ce:inf>} shell consists of 16 VO5 square pyramids by sharing edges and corners with 20 μ<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-O atoms and 2 μ<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-O atoms. The other 16 oxygen atoms are terminal in the polar positions of the 16 VO5 square pyramids. The geometry around vanadium (V1) in the 4 VO5 units is defined by four basal μ<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-O groups and an apical <ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>-oxygen which in turn is linearly bonded to the Ni(II) center and then {V1–O–Ni–O–V1} bonds, which link [V<ce:inf loc="post">16</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">38</ce:inf>F]<ce:sup loc="post">4−</ce:sup> clusters, are formed. The square pyramidal geometry around vanadium (V2 and V3) in eight of the 16 VO5 groups is defined by a terminal oxo group and four μ<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-O atoms of the shell. The geometry around vanadium (V4) in the remaining 4 VO5 units is defined by three μ<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-O groups, one μ<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-O group and one terminal oxygen atom.</ce:para><ce:section-title>Thermogravimetric analysis</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">Thermogravimetric analysis of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>4</ce:bold> reveals a continuous weight loss (36.7% for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, 35.5% for <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, 36.1% for <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> and 35.8% for <ce:bold>4</ce:bold>) until 429<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, 421<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, 431<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C and 428<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, respectively, corresponding to the removal of water molecules, the guest 4,4′-bpy molecule and four coordinated 4,4′-bpy molecules (calc.36.1% for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, 36.2% for <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, 36.9% for <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> and 36.3% for <ce:bold>4</ce:bold>). In compound <ce:bold>5</ce:bold>, the TG curve shows four weight loss steps, which suggests a multiple-stage decomposition process. Heating from about 25 to 130<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C leads to the loss (weight loss of ca. 2.03%) of three crystal H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O molecules per formula unit (calc. 1.79%). The next three weight loss steps (45.23%), occurring between 180 and 596<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, correspond to the loss of three 2,2′-bpy molecules per formula unit (calc. 46.68%).</ce:para><ce:section-title>Magnetic properties of compounds <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>5</ce:bold>
</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">The variable-temperature magnetic susceptibilities of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>′, <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> were measured between 2 and 300<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K at 10<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>000<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Oe. The magnetic data of compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>′ is included for comparison. The thermal variations of <ce:italic>χ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">m</ce:inf>
<ce:italic>T</ce:italic> and 1/<ce:italic>χ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">m</ce:inf> are displayed in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig6"></ce:float-anchor> (where <ce:italic>χ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">m</ce:inf> is the measured magnetic susceptibility). In the case of compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>′, <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>4</ce:bold>, the <ce:italic>χ</ce:italic>

<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1 for V<ce:sup loc="post">4+</ce:sup>) is higher than the expected value (<ce:italic>χ</ce:italic>

cln_elements.clean_text:
Description of the crystal structure

Single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that compounds 1-4 are isomorphous. They have similar molecular formulas and crystal structures, hence only the structure of 1 will be discussed in detail. The crystal structure of 1 can be described as a three-dimensional framework constructed from helical metal-organic coordination polymers [{Nibpy}2+] n  cations, [V16O38(F)]4- cluster anions, guest 4,4'-bpy and water molecules ( ). The [V16O38F]4- cluster, with S4 symmetry, is composed of a {V16O38} shell with an encapsulated F- ion in the center. The 16 V atoms are arranged at the surface of the shell with radius of 3.57±0.21Å from the central haloid ion. The host {V16O38} shell consists of 16 VO5 square pyramids by sharing edges and corners with 20 μ3-O atoms and 2 μ2-O atoms. The other 16 oxygen atoms are terminal in the polar positions of the 16 VO5 square pyramids. The geometry around vanadium (V1) in the 4 VO5 units is defined by four basal μ3-O groups and an apical μ-oxygen which in turn is linearly bonded to the Ni(II) center and then {V1-O-Ni-O-V1} bonds, which link [V16O38F]4- clusters, are formed. The square pyramidal geometry around vanadium (V2 and V3) in eight of the 16 VO5 groups is defined by a terminal oxo group and four μ3-O atoms of the shell. The geometry around vanadium (V4) in the remaining 4 VO5 units is defined by three μ3-O groups, one μ2-O group and one terminal oxygen atom.

Thermogravimetric analysis

Thermogravimetric analysis of 1-4 reveals a continuous weight loss (36.7% for 1, 35.5% for 2, 36.1% for 3 and 35.8% for 4) until 429°C, 421°C, 431°C and 428°C, respectively, corresponding to the removal of water molecules, the guest 4,4'-bpy molecule and four coordinated 4,4'-bpy molecules (calc.36.1% for 1, 36.2% for 2, 36.9% for 3 and 36.3% for 4). In compound 5, the TG curve shows four weight loss steps, which suggests a multiple-stage decomposition process. Heating from about 25 to 130°C leads to the loss (weight loss of ca. 2.03%) of three crystal H2O molecules per formula unit (calc. 1.79%). The next three weight loss steps (45.23%), occurring between 180 and 596°C, correspond to the loss of three 2,2'-bpy molecules per formula unit (calc. 46.68%).

Magnetic properties of compounds 3, 4 and 5 

The variable-temperature magnetic susceptibilities of 1', 3 and 4 were measured between 2 and 300K at 10000Oe. The magnetic data of compound 1' is included for comparison. The thermal variations of χ m T and 1/χ m are displayed in   (where χ m is the measured magnetic susceptibility). In the case of compounds 1', 3 and 4, the χ m T products at 300K are 3.02emuKmol-1 (4.92 μ B), 6.47emuKmol-1 (7.19 μ B) and 8.82emuKmol-1 (8.40 μ B), respectively. The χ m T values of 1' and 4 are smaller than the expected values for two uncorrelated M2+ (Ni2+: S =1, Mn2+: S =5/2) and seven V4+ (S =1/2) centers per formula unit (χ m T (1')=4.63emuKmol-1, 6.08 μ B; χ m T (4)=11.38emuKmol-1, 9.54 μ B), but the χ m T value of 3(two uncoupled S =3/2 for Co2+, seven uncoupled S =1 for V4+) is higher than the expected value (χ m T (3)=6.38emuKmol-1, 7.14 μ B). The products χ m T increase on cooling to a maximum 5.93emuKmol-1 at 8K for 1', 9.00emuKmol-1 at 50K for 3 and 12.70emuKmol-1 at 48K for 4, which indicates the presence of ferrimagnetic exchange coupling. Subsequently, the curves drop abruptly below 8K, 50K and 48K for 1', 3 and 4, respectively, which may be caused by the zero-field splitting contributions, intercluster magnetic interactions or saturation effects are likely to influence the data in this temperature range. The measured data of 1', 3 and 4 were fitted by using the Curie-Weiss equation χ m = C m/(T - θ) at T >150K, where C m is the Curie constant and θ is the Weiss constant, with C m =2.39emuKmol-1 and θ =65.85K for 1', C m =5.32emuKmol-1 and θ =55.91K for 3 and C m =7.16emuKmol-1 and θ =60.22K for 4.

cln_elements.clean_text: The variable-temperature magnetic susceptibility of 5 was also measured between 2 and 300K at 10000Oe. χ m T versus T shows a value of 6.68emuKmol-1 (7.31 μ B) at 300K, higher than the expected total value (6.00emuKmol-1, 6.93 μ B) of eight uncoupled S =1/2 spins of V4+ atoms and three uncoupled S =1 spins of Ni2+ atoms (). The χ m T values remain almost constant from 300K to 18K, and then decrease on further cooling, reaching a value of 3.74emuKmol-1 at 2K, which indicates paramagnetic properties in compound 5. The fit for the curve of the 1/χ m versus T plot of 5 to the Curie-Weiss law gives a good result in the temperature range 2-300K with C m =6.66emuKmol-1 and θ =0.20K (see   ).
